Qu Yuan, you are a great poet and a loyal patriot. You moved heaven and earth with your words of Li Sao and moved gods and ghosts with your loyalty. Now, you will shoulder the responsibility of reviving the country, expanding the territory and writing a new legend.
Qu Yuan: The Three Kingdoms
Li Sao

After you build or conquer a city, it enters the "Fill in the blanks" state: within five rounds, the city's name is changed to half a sentence of "Li Sao", and the player needs to change the city's name to the corresponding other half of the "Li Sao" poem within the specified time (at the beginning of the round, the AI ​​player has a 15% chance of answering correctly). [NEWLINE]At the beginning of the round, if the answer is correct, the city will immediately complete the current production content, gain +20% [ICON_FOOD][ICON_Production][ICON_SCIENCE][ICON_Culture][ICON_Faith][ICON_Gold] total output, +1 [ICON_Amenities] amenity, and have a chance to gain 1 builder. [NEWLINE]If you fail to answer correctly within the specified time, the city will lose 1 [ICON_Amenities] amenity. If the city has at least two people, the city residents may rebel because you failed to answer the "Fill in the blanks" correctly. [NEWLINE]Note: Cities can enter the "Li Sao Fill in the Blanks" state repeatedly. The last correct but unanswered questions will be directly settled, and the unanswered questions will be overwritten. [NEWLINE]You own the featured project "{LOC_PROJECT_SANGUOSHA_QU_YUAN_HYLS_NAME}"[NEWLINE]Every 10 turns, a random city of yours will enter the "Li Sao Fill in the Blanks" state.
Carrying forward Li Sao
{LOC_LEADER_SANGUOSHA_QU_YUAN_NAME} leader's unique project. Once completed, a random city of each major civilization will enter the "Li Sao Filling in the Blanks" state.
Ying
Chain
Quest

You can find a chain of iron chains each round. The first attack on an enemy unit in each round will automatically trigger the "chain chain" effect, and all enemy units connected to the target will be damaged by this attack. At the end of the round, if you did not trigger the "chain chain" effect in this round, the chain will be automatically recast, and you will get [ICON_Gold] coins equivalent to one third of your current [ICON_Science][ICON_Culture] value.

I am a descendant of Emperor Gaoyang. My father is called Boyong. I was born on the Gengyin year of the Sheti year in the first month of the year. The Emperor looked at me for the first time and bestowed upon me a good name. My name is Zhengze and my courtesy name is Lingjun.
The whole world is turbid, but I am the only one who is clear; everyone is drunk, but I am the only one who is sober.

Qu Yuan (about 340-278 BC), surnamed Mi (also known as Nie), clan Qu, given name Ping, courtesy name Yuan, also called himself Zhengze, courtesy name Lingjun, was born in Zigui, Danyang, Chu State (now Yichang City, Hubei Province), a poet and politician of Chu State during the Warring States Period. He was a descendant of Qu Xia, son of King Wu of Chu, Xiong Tong (some say the origin of the Qu clan is Qu Zha, a Chu State man in the early Western Zhou Dynasty).

Qu Yuan received a good education when he was young, was well-informed and ambitious. In his early years, he was trusted by King Huai of Chu and served as Zuotu and Sanlu Dafu, and was in charge of domestic and foreign affairs. He advocated "beautiful politics", advocated the selection of talents and the improvement of laws, and advocated the alliance with Qi to resist Qin. Because he was excluded and slandered by the nobles, he was exiled to Hanbei and Yuanxiang River Basin successively. In 278 BC, after the Qin army captured Yingdu of Chu, he drowned himself in Miluo River and died for Chu.

Qu Yuan is a great patriotic poet in Chinese history, the founder of Chinese romantic literature, the creator and representative writer of "Chu Ci", who opened up the tradition of "fragrant grass and beautiful women" and was praised as the "ancestor of Chu Ci". Song Yu, Tang Le and Jing Cha, famous poets of Chu State, were all influenced by Qu Yuan. The emergence of Qu Yuan's works marked the beginning of a new era for Chinese poetry from singing elegant songs to romantic creations. His main works include "Li Sao", "Nine Songs", "Nine Chapters" and "Heavenly Questions". "Chu Ci", with Qu Yuan's works as the main body, is one of the sources of Chinese romantic literature and has a profound influence on later poetry. It has become a shining pearl in the history of Chinese literature, "elegant and magnificent words, outstanding in the world". "The road is long and arduous, I will search up and down", Qu Yuan's "seeking" spirit has become a noble spirit believed in and pursued by people of lofty ideals in later generations.

In 1953, on the 2230th anniversary of Qu Yuan's death, the World Peace Council passed a resolution to designate Qu Yuan as one of the four great cultural figures in the world to be commemorated that year.
